{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3000928,"name":"Bärin W.","username":"BrooklynTony198","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brooklyntony198/{size}/10264_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-01T00:09:39.202Z","cooked":"

Our team’s robot necessitates having a counterweight to balance correctly while hanging. However, this whole assembly adds another 10lbs~ to the robot, and I’m trying to cut weight…

I had this silly idea a few days ago about using our battery as the actual weight for this counterweight. I’ve scoured the game manual and forums and it’s technically legal, but its still really sketchy to us.

Screen Shot 2022-01-31 at 2.01.51 PM227×643 64.1 KB
Screen Shot 2022-01-31 at 2.02.00 PM534×537 47.8 KB

This is the general mockup of the idea, and it does work… in theory. Any thoughts about this? Do you all think it would even pass inspection? We kinda are not planning to use this idea, but I was still wondering if it would even be legal or feasible.

I know 433 did something similar, but not as drastic, in 2015 to shift their CoM when carrying a full stack of totes. It’s a cool idea in theory, but I’d probably say it’s more risky than worth it in most cases.

67 posts were split to a new topic: Inspection Culture & Applied Rules

Hey y’all, moved the bulk of these posts to a new thread not related to battery counterweight questions, as while the inspection rules & culture discussion is important this will make it easier to find and keeping the concept from clogging this thread up if there’s more discussion here.

","post_number":9,"post_type":3,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2022-02-01T18:19:39.298Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":571,"readers_count":570,"score":129.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":401852,"topic_slug":"using-a-battery-as-a-counterweight","display_username":"Kim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/inspection-culture-applied-rules/401917","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"[Split Thread] Inspection Culture & Applied Rules","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":28161,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"she/her | old curmudgeon"},"action_code":"split_topic","post_url":"/t/using-a-battery-as-a-counterweight/401852/9","custom_user_title":"she/her | old curmudgeon","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3001249,"name":"","username":"CBryan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbryan/{size}/254420_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-01T16:52:46.212Z","cooked":"

@BrooklynTony198 this is genuinely a really cool idea!

Reminds me of our 2013 robot Viper!

https://youtu.be/bYgpg0k4uwI?t=111

If I remember correctly… Viper had a lot of electronics and the battery biased forward to generate the swing during the climb. Perhaps there is a way for your team to attempt something like this as well? It appears you have the mock-up on a swerve drive which gives you plenty of packaging space down low!

It’s always exciting to see some cute or innovative take on a challenge. Please keep us posted if this idea takes more shape than just a mock-up!

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2022-02-01T18:32:35.491Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":651,"readers_count":650,"score":255.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":401852,"topic_slug":"using-a-battery-as-a-counterweight","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://youtu.be/bYgpg0k4uwI?t=111","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":1},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/split-thread-inspection-culture-applied-rules/401917/47","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"[Split Thread] Inspection Culture & Applied Rules","clicks":13}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34059,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-battery-as-a-counterweight/401852/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3001440,"name":"Al Skierkiewicz Learn Something New, Every Day!","username":"Al_Skierkiewicz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/al_skierkiewicz/{size}/110877_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-01T19:35:51.935Z","cooked":"

I would think that R203 would be one of the obvious rules to look at but I would add that the implementation above adds a few feet of primary wiring. (Check R502 too) Since all robot current flows through this wire, adding length to it makes your robot design more susceptible to brown out. As a rule of thumb, every foot of #6 wire will drop 0.05 volts at 100 amps. So figuring adding 6 ft. (out and back remember) at 500 amps would drop the input to the PDP/PDH by 1.5 volts even with a fresh battery. Since it is common for robots under drive to drop down to 7-8 volts, 1.5 gets you into the critical brownout zone. You also need to prove that the battery is mounted so as to not leave the robot under R606. That would get you disabled for sure. I realize that designing a secure battery mount might add a lot of weight you would want to use somewhere else.
By all means, mount the battery near the back of the robot to take advantage of the weight.

Gets my +1 as the solution to the initial question(s) by OP.

Thanks for chiming in Al.

[Split Thread] Inspection Culture & Applied Rules

I’ve been doing FRC for 3 years already, and I kinda know what does and doesn’t work, but its always a good exercise to come up with the not-obvious ideas. Sometimes they actually are the best ideas.

At first I wanted to do some weird angled hook system to climb easily, but that didn’t work. Then the idea was to launch the robot upwards using pneumatics (i watched too many battlebots episodes), then it was the tilting elevator style we are designing right now.

I mentioned this idea to our electrical lead and they almost fainted. I almost want to keep coming up with these ideas to scare the other leads on my team haha!

@BrooklynTony198 moving my response here back to your original thread. You’re on the right track of brainstorming ideas. I’m definitely laughing at your joke about scaring the other leads on your team with outlandish ideas, and in a slightly more serious note would actually highly suggest involving your team members in the other engineering divisions of your team in your brainstorming process. Often-times they’ll be able to point out ideas and considerations with how your designs interact with their division of the team, and can help improve the design in ways that benefit everyone.

I strongly suspect it will be difficult to prevent the battery cables from getting snagged somewhere. The bend radius of the 6 AWG, or larger, cables will mean you will have to be very clever with cable routing and/or will require a fair amount of space for the battery cables. The method the OP used to move the battery largely mitigates such issues.

A second factor is the long battery cables will lead to greater voltage drop so your robot will brown-out easier.

The Game Manual states that the battery must be secure in the robot. Since such a battery mounting scheme is highly unusual, you need to be prepared to prove the battery is secure in all circumstances.

Are you able to think of a different climbing method that doesn’t require moving the battery to change the CG? Engineering requires making trade-offs. Good designs are the result of making good decisions based on solid facts and data.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2022-02-24T20:28:21.360Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":287,"readers_count":286,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":401852,"topic_slug":"using-a-battery-as-a-counterweight","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-a-battery-as-a-counterweight/401852/19","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3013064,"name":"Al Skierkiewicz Learn Something New, Every Day!","username":"Al_Skierkiewicz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/al_skierkiewicz/{size}/110877_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-26T01:10:21.941Z","cooked":"

Berkeli,
Interesting concept. The simple answer is yes, the obvious answer was discussed in part by Phil above. I always point out that all robot current flows from and to the battery through the #6 wire. If you were to secure the wire at the midpoint of travel, that would minimize the length required for your battery cable. However, in trying to keep the CG very low in the robot, the traveling battery as you presented, takes a lot of room and leaves a lot of weight for higher up in the robot. Of course you might run a few calculations and find you don’t need the full travel you show in your drawing. Perhaps a few inches or so might be all you need. I would naturally recommend some absorbitive material at each end so that the battery does not take hit at either end of travel. Repeated travel with the sudden stop may eventually damage the battery case. I have heard someone propose putting the battery sled on a motor so that exact position could be accurately controlled. That might work, and it would be pretty cool, but…it still makes me shiver to think of a battery moving around inside the robot. If you do choose to build it I would like to see some pics.
